Lymphocytes primarily consist of T cells, B cells and natural killer (NK) cells. T cells regulate both innate and adaptive immune responses. B cells produce antibodies and NK cells can recognize and kill stressed cells in the absence of antibodies [70], [71], [72], [73]. Although we can use a saturating function to set the maximum death rate, as used by Pawelek et al. to study the control of influenza virus infection by the adaptive immune response [68], it will introduce an extra parameter for estimation from data fitting. Because we aim to model the viral elimination in the end of infection, the exponentially increasing function is reasonable for this purpose.
